name: St. John (João) de Britto
short_profile: A visionary and deeply empathetic Jesuit missionary who adopted local Tamil customs to evangelize effectively; highly disciplined, ascetic, and emotionally resilient, he combined strategic long-term planning with profound cultural empathy and spiritual conviction.
core_traits: Deep empathic inculturation and people-orientation (auxiliary Fe)
values: Obedience to conscience and religious vocation
Respectful cultural adaptation for the sake of relationship

subculture: Inculturated Tamil ascetic subculture (adopted saffron/Yellow cotton, local customs)
norms: Obedience to ecclesiastical hierarchy and vows
Use of local linguistic and cultural idioms to teach faith

education.highest_level: Jesuit formation (advanced theological/philosophical training; comparable to graduate-level seminary education)
education.field: Theology, Philosophy, Classical Languages (Latin); later self-taught in Tamil and Sanskrit studies for mission work
strengths: Systematic theological reasoning and moral logic
Strategic planning for long-term missionary goals
weaknesses: Rigidity on non-negotiable doctrinal matters when pressured
Physical fragility from extreme ascetic practices
key_experiences: Entering the Society of Jesus and rigorous Jesuit training
Volunteering for and living in the Madurai mission—adopting local dress, language, and customs (inculturation)
Repeated arrests, imprisonment, and ultimately martyrdom in Oriyur (1693)

history: Born João de Britto in Lisbon, Portugal, 1647; entered the Society of Jesus and prepared for mission work.
Served as a missionary primarily in the Madurai region (Tamil Nadu), adopting local dress, learning Tamil (and studying Sanskrit), and converting thousands through inculturation and catechesis.
Arrested for refusing idolatry and certain local demands; imprisoned, tortured, and martyred at Oriyur (4 February 1693); beatified (1853) and canonized (1947).

quotes.context: Closing line from a prison letter to P. Manuel Rodrigues (30 July 1686) after his first arrest — a summary statement of identity and offered witness.

quotes.text: Tenho no meu Marraven aberta grande porta à conversão: mas são muitos os adversários... Quando esta chegar às mãos de V. R. espero em Deus de ter baptizado alli mais de seis mil.
quotes.context: From a missionary letter to P. Luiz Pereira (Madurai mission), 23 May — reporting mission progress, optimism about conversions, and a pragmatic, strategic tone about work among the people.

quotes.text: Agora espero padecer a morte por meu Deus e meu Senhor... Do cárcere de Urgur, 3 de fevereiro de 1693.
quotes.context: From his final letter (3 February 1693) to Father Francisco Laynes, written on the eve of his execution — calm acceptance of death and framing suffering as participation in divine will.
